webTitle: RBS set to benefit from the Andy Murray effect

fields.bodyText: It is a well-worn criticism of Fleet Street scribes that they refer to Andy Murray as Scottish when he loses a tennis match, and British during his (now frequent) triumphs. Likewise, the City made Royal Bank of Scotland firmly Caledonian during the financial crisis but, as the bank hauls itself back towards something that can be spun as health, there are rumblings that it might not be Scottish much longer. The theory will become topical again this week as RBS boss Stephen Hester departs and is replaced by Ross McEwan. McEwan may sound Scottish but he is, in fact, a Kiwi whose to-do list includes tasks such as the so-called "good bank, bad bank" split, sorting out RBS's accident-prone IT systems, floating its US arm Citizens and deciding whether to shut the squeezed investment bank. Also requiring thought is moving RBS's headquarters from Edinburgh, now a pressing consideration as Scotland's independence referendum looms. He will discover some early preparation has been done. Last year, RBS chairman Sir Philip Hampton told the House of Lords economic affairs committee that potential changes such as corporation tax increases might persuade the bank to move. He also said that "small countries don't often have big banks" or, put another way: if RBS is approaching a run of form, it belongs in the United Kingdom. Has Captain Hanning made a major blunder? Ian Hannam, the mining dealmaker lauded as a City rainmaker during the boom (but rarely since), will again play a starring role this week as his ongoing courtroom drama limps to a close. You'll recall how the former Territorial Army captain is fighting to restore his reputation by appealing against last year's £450,000 Financial Services Authority fine for market abuse, and lawyers from both sides are due to utter closing remarks on Thursday. Even if Hannam wins, there will be those who wonder what he's really achieved. The hearing has revealed uncomfortable details such as his former employer JP Morgan Cazenove monitoring his email and telephone calls; has prompted reminders about his involvement in the disastrous Bumi flotation; and has cost the financier more than double the prospective fine in legal expenses. The court also heard him claim that he may have fabricated the contents of incriminating emails that form the case against him. So, Hannam is either guilty of market abuse (which the City frowns on – at least when you get caught) or he misled a business contact (possibly a greater sin in the Square Mile). Neither outcome is great advertising for his new firm, which we will plug for him here. It's called Strand Partners. Boring Bank meeting becomes hot property Typically, you have to be a dedicated economics wonk to bother studying the minutes of the Bank of England's financial policy committee. The documents are full of tedious phrases such as "there were a range of views among members on what precisely should be disclosed from a future stress test", meaning that you are strongly advised not to read them while operating heavy machinery. On Tuesday, however, when minutes of the FPC's September gathering are released, there will almost certainly be a leap in the number of interested readers. New subscribers will be searching for clues that reveal committee members' views on the housing market, following last week's news that the FPC must now do annual reviews of chancellor George Osborne's Help to Buy (the next election) scheme. Help to Buy – which is ostensibly designed to assist those struggling to get on the housing ladder by providing taxpayer insurance of mortgages – was originally due to be assessed by the FPC only after its first three years. But now the chancellor seems to have conceded the need for more regular refereeing, following criticism that the scheme might be inflationary, as it potentially increases demand for housing while doing little about supply. And you don't have to be an economics wonk to have heard of that theory.

webTitle: Vince Cable prepares to launch crackdown on executive pay

fields.standfirst: New proposals will include binding votes and a requirement for easier-to-understand figures for boardroom remuneration
fields.body:
The 30-year battle over boardroom pay enters a new phase on Tuesday when business secretary Vince Cable hands shareholders the power to throw out executive remuneration policies that are too generous and forces companies to simplify the data they provide about what they pay top bosses.

Cable is to give shareholders a binding vote on company pay policies once every three years and an advisory vote every year. He is also demanding companies publish a single figure for bosses' pay annually, rather than the wide range of numbers currently provided, which often require expert knowledge to add up. It is the latest of several efforts to clamp down on pay since the 1980s, when BOC Group's then chief executive, Richard Giordano, was the UK's highest-paid director and accused of executive excess for his £271,000-a-year pay deal.

Labour handed shareholders their first vote on remuneration policies in 2002 following the row over "rewards for failure" for directors of the failed telecoms company Marconi. That vote was only advisory and shareholders usually preferred to protest in private rather than show their anger in public. But the mood changed last year, when the 2012 company AGM season became known as the "shareholder spring". A record six pay reports were voted down and Cable, angered by spiralling executive pay that jarred with the government's austerity policies, decided to beef up the advisory vote.

On average, British bosses now earn 69 times more than the average pay of their workforce – although some get rewards equal to the pay of several hundred staff – and top pay has quadrupled in the last decade. Cable is concerned that these huge rises have not been related to performance. "At the same time, company reports have become increasingly complicated without giving shareholders the right sort of details they need in order to evaluate performance," he says.

However, he has backed away from a proposal that companies put employees on their remuneration committees and is relying on shareholders to monitor pay more effectively. But he insists: "The signs are that we are moving in the right direction. In the last year we've seen some restraint. Our reforms mean shareholders will now no longer be kept in the dark."

Robert Talbut at Royal London Asset Management says that the introduction of the new rules is already having an effect: "Companies are doing everything they can to avoid any confrontation next year. There is a lot of consultation taking place already."

The first companies to comply with the new rules will be those with financial years ending in September. Catering group Compass, cigarette company Imperial Tobacco and easyJet are among those to fall into this category. Their annual meetings take place in the new year.

Investors will have two new votes:

■ A binding vote on pay policy that needs majority support from those shareholders who vote every three years. The vote, which becomes binding from the next financial year, has been introduced to deal with serial offenders who simply ignore or fail to respond to pay protests – such as satellite operator Inmarsat and advertising company WPP, which have seen consecutive rebellions.

Andrew Stanger, a partner at international law firm Mayer Brown, says those companies that fail to secure shareholder support will need to hold an extraordinary general meeting shortly afterwards. He also believes firms will need to take care: "If a company makes a payment outside the policy then the payment is void and all the directors are individually liable to the company to reimburse the company and the individual."

■ An annual advisory vote on last year's pay settlements. This is intended to provide investors with a say on the actual pay awarded to directors, which needs to be in line with the policy approved by investors through the binding vote. If the annual vote is lost, the company will have to put the policy back to the binding vote on pay.

Companies are already required to disclose salaries, bonuses and information about shares released from long-term incentive schemes. But previously they could provide the information in any format, which made it difficult to make comparisons with rivals. The new pay rules will require a single figure to be reported for the total pay directors receive, covering salary, benefits, annual bonus, shares released from incentive schemes and pension contributions. Companies will also have to provide all details of payoffs.

Firms will also have to provide a breakdown of the amount spent on pay, the amount distributed to shareholders and any other significant outgoings. This will allow investors to see at a glance whether they are getting their fair share – and will highlight high pay. At Barclays, for instance, it would have shown that, in 2011, the bank paid out £2.1bn in bonuses – three times the £700m paid to shareholders in dividends.

webTitle: Every little hurts: Tesco's battle to regain markets and reputation

fields.bodyText: Britain's biggest supermarket has stores in nearly every town, but Tesco's crown has slipped after its first profit warning in 20 years and questions over its food quality, stores, customer service and international ambitions. This week, Philip Clarke will report on how his efforts to revive the retailer are progressing in the company's six-monthly update. Clarke, who took charge in 2011, announced a six-point plan to get the vital UK business back on its feet 18 months ago following its first profit fall in two decades. He promised to improve service, make prices and promotions more attractive and stores more friendly. Yet UK performance remains poor, and analysts predict underlying sales will be flat or slightly down. The latest market data, meanwhile, indicates that Tesco is continuing to lose market share both to discounters such as Aldi and quality experts like Waitrose. Tesco operates as far afield as South Korea and Turkey, but what happens in the UK is critical, as business at home accounts for about three-quarters of profits. The good news this week is that profits will be up slightly in the UK – but analysts don't expect that performance to offset problems abroad – so overall Clarke will have to reveal that profits have slipped again. It's clear he faces challenges overseas and online, and investors will be watching this week's announcements closely for more detail about how Tesco intends to fight back. Stores After two decades of building ever larger stores, Clarke last year called an end to the supermarket space race, conceding that shoppers had fallen out of love with large out-of-town branches. Tesco will now stick to sites of less than 80,000 sq ft, and Clarke is selling off development land. But with fewer big stores planned, and an already vast number of convenience outlets, how can Tesco rebuild its declining market share in the UK? Clarke is continuing to open some new branches, but is spending £1bn to "put the love back" into existing stores, which had become too clinical and where service standards had also slipped. The retailer has put in thousands more staff to improve service and has been testing new ideas in existing stores, such as artisan bakeries run by Euphorium, a specialist baker based in Islington in London; and upmarket Harris + Hoole coffee shops and Giraffe restaurants – all businesses that Tesco has invested in over the past two years. But so far just three out of at least 50 stores with too much space have been tackled. The company is also using data from its Clubcard loyalty scheme to help tailor the product range and environment to suit local markets more effectively. But, again, just a handful of sites have had a facelift to date. City investors and analysts will want to hear from Clarke how he can do more, cost-effectively, to revive the rest of Tesco's estate. Having already written down the value of land banked for development, but no longer needed, by £800m, Clarke must also explain how the supermarket can dispose of its assets without further losses. Prices, food, image Last year, Clarke conceded that Tesco's prices had lost their competitive edge. Since then, the company's image has been tarnished further by its links to the horsemeat scandal, strawberry mis-selling and most recently a "British" pork chop that tests suggested came from elsewhere. Perhaps Clarke's toughest job is to turn around customer mistrust of the quality of Tesco's food following all those scandals. Despite the economic downturn, strong sales growth at Sainsbury's, Waitrose and Marks & Spencer show that shoppers see good quality food as important, even when money is tight. Tesco has promised to get more meat from the UK and Ireland but so far has only announced definite plans to source 100% of its fresh chicken here, where it is merely catching up with rivals. The retailer recently launched a fight back with a "love every mouthful" marketing campaign and has reorganised stores to make fresh food more prominent. Andrew Kasoulis, an analyst at Credit Suisse, suggests that Tesco's fresh food sales are now rising but other retail watchers say Tesco must invest more in the quality of its food to convince shoppers it has changed. An important part of that will be the relaunch of Tesco's "Finest" range in the next few weeks. One smart move is the company's "price promise" promotion, where it refunds the difference if shoppers could have paid less for their basket of goods at its three main rivals. The deal is similar to Sainsbury's successful Brand Match campaign, in helping to convince customers that they don't need to shop around – but there are other competitors. While some shoppers chasing quality are heading to upmarket rivals, others seeking value are deserting for discounters such as Lidl and Aldi. Tesco recently revamped its low-priced Everyday Value range to help it to compete against the discounters, but some analysts argue that what the grocer really needs, to keep shoppers loyal, is to reduce its profit margins and make its main Tesco brand cheaper. Technology Tesco led the way in online shopping and is still by far the biggest internet grocer. But competition has hotted up. Clarke has realised that technology and the internet are a key part of Tesco's future and is now responding with a wave of initiatives. Last week, the supermarket launched the Hudl, its own tablet computer – perhaps the most positive news to come out of Tesco for some time. The gadget, which has so far been well received and is priced £119, or less than £100 with Clubcard points – shows the company being innovative and bold. Its performance will be watched closely, but perhaps Hudl's most important role is to tie Tesco customers into fast-growing online services, which are all available using one button nestled in the corner of the Hudl screen. A specialist centre in Farringdon, London, is about to open where 275 IT experts will be developing a suite of Tesco apps for mobile devices. The company has also invested in Rainmaking Loft, a workspace in St Katharine Docks near the Tower of London, for young tech entrepreneurs whom Tesco can tap for new ideas. It is also developing Blinkbox, a service to stream films and TV, which it bought two years ago and should allow the company to go head-to-head with Netflix and Lovefilm. By Christmas it will also offer an ebook service. The company's new army of young IT specialists is expected to dream up exciting ways to combine big retail power with the internet, which will be vital if Tesco is to remain relevant. The retailer has also been expanding its click-and-collect grocery service, with plans to double the number of stores where shoppers can pick up goods ordered online to 300 by next spring. It is also rolling out collection points for items such as fashion and homewares to its vast estate of convenience stores after increasing the number of products available on the site to 300,000. International Tesco was once proud of its status as Britain's most successful retailer overseas. But that image has been battered in the last two years as Clarke decided to scrap Fresh & Easy, a failed venture in the US, at a cost of more than £1bn. He has also pulled out of Japan – costing another £40m – and last month did a deal to fold Tesco's 130 Chinese stores into a joint venture with a larger local partner. Analysts viewed the move – nine years after Tesco's first store in the country – as a surrender. In his previous role as head of international operations, Clarke unveiled plans to open 80 vast shopping malls across China that would have made its retail portfolio bigger than the UK. But the closures have not put an end to Tesco's overseas problems. Next week Clarke is expected to report a decline in profits and sales in nearly every country of operation over the last six months – with poor trade in Europe, particularly Poland and Turkey, adding to difficulties in Korea. Some analysts argue Clarke should withdraw from markets where sales are in reverse, but with fewer opportunities for growth at home, he needs to find new areas of expansion – and getting the formula right in Europe is vital.

webTitle: 'Red Ed' Miliband? Not really, but at least he's made a start

fields.bodyText: Nothing about the reaction to Ed Miliband's pledge to cap consumers' energy bills last week should have been surprising. The big six power firms issued grim threats that the lights would go out, and the Tories claimed Labour were dragging Britain back to the bad old statist days of the 1970s. The utility barons' furious reaction was easy to write off, as special pleading, and will have done Miliband no harm at all: along with bankers, fat cat energy bosses (Centrica's Sam Laidlaw took home £5m in each of the last two years) are among the most reviled of the capitalist "predators" the Labour leader says he wants to tame. A windfall tax, 1997-style, might have been economically cleaner, and could have been tweaked later in the event of a sharp rise in wholesale prices. But a price cap for shivering families is much better politics. It directly targets one of the biggest outgoings for many households and puts flesh on the bones of what had previously been Miliband's rather abstract notion of a "cost-of-living crisis". Since it came ready-packaged with a longer-term plan for fixing the dysfunctional way the energy market works – by splitting production and supply – it also avoided being a tokenistic gesture. The second outraged claim, that Labour is returning to its lefty, nationalising, interventionist roots, bears closer examination, because it says a lot about the state of politics in Britain today. To some extent, the left/right, nationalise-it/let-the-market-rip dichotomy has always been a red herring. Conservative governments, not least this one, have always "intervened" in markets: that's part of the state's job. While George Osborne will inevitably accuse Miliband of being an unreformed, nanny-statist, trade union stooge at his own conference outing this week, the centrepiece of the chancellor's March budget was Help to Buy, a scheme that involves the taxpayer subsidising mortgages. His rationale of fixing a "market failure" could equally well be applied to Labour's plan. Miliband's suggestion last week that Labour could force developers sitting on empty land with planning permission to get on with building or face sanctions was aired earlier this year by the International Monetary Fund, hardly a bastion of socialism; and the Tory mayor of London, Boris Johnson, has promised to make increasing use of compulsory purchase orders to deal with the same problem. With Ed Balls asking the Office for Budget Responsibility to confirm it can barely get a cigarette paper between his post-2015 spending plans and Osborne's, it's not surprising there's a school of thought that, in concrete policy terms, there's little to choose between the parties economically. Labour has no intention of abandoning central bank independence or junking fiscal prudence. Yet for all that, Miliband will have been happy with the "Red Ed" sound and fury that followed last week's speech, because he believes New Labour took on too much of what his adviser Lord (Stewart) Wood describes as the post-1979 settlement – and he's ready to junk it. In an article in the latest Political Quarterly, Wood elucidates what he takes the phrase One Nation Labour to mean; and part of it is rejecting the Thatcherite faith in "maximally free markets, deregulation, minimal taxation for the wealthiest and trickle-down economics". So taking on the energy companies is not just a bid to pep up the faithful and give Labour candidates something to offer swing voters on the doorstep: it's a conscious statement of intent – and the more conciliatory tone of some Tories later in the week suggested Miliband's on to something. The extraordinarily traumatic financial and economic crisis that began more than five years ago has forced pained politicians to rethink the way banks are regulated, but there has been scant acknowledgement that there are lessons for the rest of UK plc, too. The boardroom largesse that made a small number of senior staff staggeringly rich and left the average worker diving into debt to maintain living standards – with destabilising effects on the economy as a whole – was hardly confined to firms in the Square Mile and Canary Wharf. Neither was reckless short-termism, nor widespread, wholesale tax avoidance, nor crappy, insecure job contracts. The coalition has made piecemeal progress in some of these areas. Vince Cable is working at the European level to end the practice of quarterly reporting, which drives boards to prioritise short-term returns over the longer-term soundness of the company, while George Osborne has backed OECD proposals for international tax reform. But the Tories' initial knee-jerk response to the energy plans – Michael Foot was mentioned more than once – betrayed the fact that for them the post-'79 settlement, with its promise to let the wealth creators rip and the market decide, is very much alive. So far, Miliband's alternative to that long-held cross-party consensus is still a fairly thin one, even after the past week: it involves building more homes and expecting the rich to bear a larger share of taxation. Wood's musings suggest that, as it is fleshed out in the runup to the 2015 election, it may also mean tougher constraints on corporate excess, better bargaining power for workers, and the restoration of the contributory principle in the welfare state. Taken together, all this just might add up to a coherent platform for making markets work better for society. As yet, there is far less of a clear vision from Labour about how best to generate sustainable economic growth, in an environment in which public money is tight, business investment has continued to decline rapidly and households remain heavily indebted. Busting open the banking sector might be a good start – but perhaps that will have to wait for next year's conference.

fields.headline: 'Red Ed' Miliband? Not really, but at least he's made a start
fields.body:
Nothing about the reaction to Ed Miliband's pledge to cap consumers' energy bills last week should have been surprising. The big six power firms issued grim threats that the lights would go out, and the Tories claimed Labour were dragging Britain back to the bad old statist days of the 1970s. The utility barons' furious reaction was easy to write off, as special pleading, and will have done Miliband no harm at all: along with bankers, fat cat energy bosses (Centrica's Sam Laidlaw took home £5m in each of the last two years) are among the most reviled of the capitalist "predators" the Labour leader says he wants to tame.

A windfall tax, 1997-style, might have been economically cleaner, and could have been tweaked later in the event of a sharp rise in wholesale prices. It directly targets one of the biggest outgoings for many households and puts flesh on the bones of what had previously been Miliband's rather abstract notion of a "cost-of-living crisis". Since it came ready-packaged with a longer-term plan for fixing the dysfunctional way the energy market works – by splitting production and supply – it also avoided being a tokenistic gesture.

webTitle: Post office staff strike over shakeup overshadowed by Royal Mail sell-off

fields.bodyText: Mary Rogers has worked at the Post Office all her life. When she started behind the counters in 1971, aged 16, Edward Heath was in Downing Street and you could buy a stamp, with freshly minted decimal coins, for 3p. Many of the customers are old friends who give her cards at Christmas. But tomorrow – along with 4,000 other post office workers – Mary will be on the picket line, a reluctant striker in an increasingly bitter industrial dispute. This will be the 12th strike since Easter Sunday, as the Post Office embarks on one of its biggest shakeups since the General Post Office was abolished in 1969. Yet, so far, the sweeping changes have attracted far less attention than the plans to sell off the Royal Mail – the delivery service that was split from the Post Office counters business in 2012. As the government begins the sale of Royal Mail in October, the Post Office is planning to turn almost one fifth of 372 flagship crown branches into smaller franchised outlets in supermarkets and newsagents. Crown offices only make up 3% of the Post Office's 11,800 branches, but they draw in 20% of customers and sell 40% of financial service products sold by the Post Office – a crucial growth area for the loss-making network. The franchise plans will not affect the bright airy crown office in Derby, where Rogers works, but she is worried about the fate of colleagues in nearby branches. "We provide such a vital service," she says. "It is a core part of the town, I don't like the idea of it being at the back of Wilko's." She also fears some of her co-workers could lose their jobs if the crown branches transfer into shops: "Our jobs, thank God, are all right. But it is about other people." The Communication Workers Union, which represents post office workers, says the franchise plans will result in the loss of 1,500 jobs, although the Post Office says there will be no compulsory redundancies and that jobs will be found for those who do not wish to leave the service. The Post Office is in talks with several large retailers, including Asda and McColl's, and hopes to replace 35 crown branches with franchised outlets by next March. It is all part of the £70m plan to create a profitable "21st-century" post office, says Roger Gale, general manager of the crown network. The crown in Derby is the model of this swish new, tech-smart Post Office. Out are the long snaking queues and the cashiers behind their "fortress" – thick glass barriers that customers often used to have to shout through. In are plush red seats, private offices for discussions with mortgage advisers – the Post Office began selling home loans last year – and cheerful advisers to guide customers around the open-plan shop floor. One post office worker shows the self-service postal machines to Jill Durbin, 71, who is sending a present to her grandson. "Oh my God, it costs more than the darn sweets," she says at the £2.60 cost of sending the small parcel. The change in the crown offices has raised alarm across the country, with councils such as Tory-led Westminster, Hastings and Manchester voting against the plans. Conservative MPs can see that their support will be damaged if post offices close, says Ben Harris-Quinney of conservative thinktank the Bow Group. "I think both the part-privatisation of the Post Office and now the full privatisation of the Royal Mail are likely to lead to post office closures," he says. "This will damage communities and the Conservative vote." Adrian Bailey, the Labour MP who chairs the parliamentary select committee on business, innovation and skills, says some unprofitable crown services have to transfer into shops to stop the network shrinking. "The fact is, not every post office can last forever," he says. The Post Office rejects claims that the franchise plans will lead to closures or poorer service. "Franchising is to make sure the Post Office stays in those towns and cities in a cost-effective and sustainable way," says Gale. The government, which is paying £1.3bn in subsidies into the Post Office over four years, wants the crown branches in profit by March 2015. "The crown network loses £37m of taxpayers' money every year and we are determined to get rid of that loss," says Gale. But for now he doesn't see any end in sight to the dispute. Nor does the union. For post office workers such as Rogers, who lose pay every time they strike, this means the strikes could continue until Christmas, the busiest time for the Post Office. "Nobody wants to go on strike. But sometimes you have to stand up and be counted," she says.
